Articles.Content:
So, I went to a car boot sale today.

I was hoping to buy some warhammer or a model, instead, look what I found!

My parents bought it for me for Â£12. I\'m actually really happy with it...

I haven\'t been so happy about getting a toy since I was like 8, I think.

Â£12?

That\'s cheap.

Makes me laugh that tonnes of children buy CDs of songs which can just be found on Youtube for the same amount...

Â£12?

That\'s cheap.

Makes me laugh that tonnes of children buy CDs of songs which can just be found on Youtube for the same amount...

Lol, yeah.

It\'s in mint condition too, apparently.

I mean, the decals were already stuck on and there were batteries in there, but it\'s in perfect condition.

SO AWESOME

It\'s in mint condition too, apparently.

I mean, the decals were already stuck on and there were batteries in there, but it\'s in perfect condition.

Shouldn\'t be too difficult, considering it\'s not older than a year

Still, for that price it\'s a no-brainer. On the other hand, the average tumble-dryer probably has more brains than this

Y u no buy Spess Mehreens?

Look in the red circle.

HAPPY NOW?

Look in the red circle.

HAPPY NOW?

YES. Happy.

Bigtrak Vs Space Marines.

I\'d love to see that.
I\'m not sure what to say. This is cool and lame at the same time. Most of the cool comes from the fact that you just happened to randomly find one in some random sale.

I remember those things from the 70s. The TV commercials had me convinced that it could do *anything!*

Looks like they were re-released in 2010. Wonder which one you\'ve got?

I remember those things from the 70s. The TV commercials had me convinced that it could do *anything!*

Looks like they were re-released in 2010. Wonder which one you\'ve got?

The instruction manual says \'ZEON LTD 2010 ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.\'

I think I have the 2010 one.

The original one was grey, not white.

Apparently it came out in \'79, much later than I thought.

Who remembers this:

Big Trak by Milton Bradley tv commercial 1979-80

Arrr!

Capt\'n Skunky

What I remember is how people used to hack them (we didn\'t call it that back then!) and interface them with a computer. You\'d then sticky tape a pen on the back, and hey presto! Instant floor turtle . . .

* And for you young\'uns that have no idea what a floor turtle was, it was basically a robot with a pen. You used a language called Logo to program it, and once your program was done you could have the robot draw you a pretty picture. Hang on *rummage rummage*

. . . Here\'s a picture of one (You will need to go to the target site, what with attachments not working and all).

http://gallery.nen.gov.uk/image78097-e2bn.html
The cursor on the screen which you moved by typing lines into LOGO was also called a Turtle.

While we\'re on the subject of LOGO, who\'s heard of the Lego version? Have a link.

I had some of the motors, wires, and touch sensors for this [got them in a large box of Lego from one of my dad\'s principal friends].
